items.title: An Urban Standard, Coolly Reimagined
items.abstract: William Lescaze’s 1935 Kramer house, like many Modernist houses, is not weathering well.

items.title: What’s Ailing City Catholic Schools Isn’t Lack of Money
items.abstract: Trustees of the Inner-City Scholarship Fund respond to an Op-Ed article.

items.title: No Deal on Teacher Evaluations; City Risks Losing $450 Million
items.abstract: The United Federation of Teachers and the Bloomberg administration blamed each other for talks breaking down even as a midnight deadline approached.

items.title: Russia, in Three Cities and ‘7 Rooms’
items.abstract: To capture Russia’s rapid changes and vast territory, Rafal Milach went small, delving into the lives of seven people reconciling their country’s past with its ever-evolving future.

items.title: In Winning Design, City Hopes to Address a Cramped Future
items.abstract: “My Micro NY” will create a building of 55 micro-units each measuring between 250 and 370 square feet, with 40 percent of the units priced to be affordable, the mayor’s office said.

items.title: State Challenges Plan to Revive City Opera
items.abstract: In a filing in federal bankrupcty court, the New York State Attorney General’s office raises several questions about a proposed reorganization of the defunct opera company.

items.title: ‘The Geography of Genius,’ by Eric Weiner
items.abstract: A tour of some of the world’s exceptional places.
keywords: The Geography of Genius: A Search for the World's Most Creative Places From Ancient Athens to Silicon Valley (Book)

items.title: As Cuomo Acts on Homeless Problem, New York City Blames State Cuts
items.abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is only one player in addressing the issue in the city, but decisions his administration has made have left the city shouldering more of the burden.

items.title: New York City Opera Will Return, and Soon, Under Reorganization Plan
items.abstract: The venerable opera company, which filed for bankruptcy protection in 2013, will be taken over by the NYCO Renaissance, which hopes to use the City Opera name by next week.

items.title: City’s Delayed Traffic Study to Guide Regulation of Uber Vehicles
items.abstract: The study, which was originally due at the end of November, aimed to assess the ride-hailing service’s effects on traffic congestion in Manhattan.

items.title: Bright Spot for N.Y.’s Struggling Schools: Pre-K
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s broader plan for public schools has been disappointing, but his universal pre-K initiative shows steady improvement.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: New York City’s Poor Were Promised Half-Priced MetroCards. They’re Still Waiting.
items.abstract: New York City was scheduled to start a discount fare program for low-income riders on Jan. 1. But the rollout has been a bit of a mess.
keywords: Community Service Society of New York

items.title: What’s Coming in New York Real Estate in 2019
items.abstract: An already soft market will get another 20,000 new apartments, making it an even stronger buyer’s and renter’s market.

items.title: Of 800,000 Poor New Yorkers, Only 30,000 Can Get the New Half-Priced MetroCards
items.abstract: The city’s new Fair Fares program will get off to a modest start, with only those receiving cash assistance from the city eligible for the discounts.

items.title: Eric Adams Takes Office as New York City’s 110th Mayor at a Perilous Moment
items.abstract: Eric Adams, the city’s second Black mayor, faces difficult decisions over how to lead New York City through the next wave of the pandemic.

items.title: New York Plans to Install ‘Vending Machines’ With Anti-Overdose Drugs
items.abstract: In addition to naloxone, a medication used to reverse opioid overdoses, the machines will distribute free syringes, toiletries and safe-sex kits.

items.title: 19 Killed in New York City’s Deadliest Fire in Decades
items.abstract: Nine children were among those who died when a space heater malfunctioned in a Bronx apartment building, city officials said.

items.title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
items.abstract: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?

items.title: The Plans for the World’s Next Largest City Are Incomplete
items.abstract: Delhi is growing far beyond the formal confines of the city, a case study in the complexity of what we call urbanization.
